instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message:
Came in with no damage seen, both sides of board and case.  Powered on as soon as I put my ammeter in, pulled 20v booted just fine, was charging battery etc.  Chalked it up to bad luck and put it back together, now it doesn't work again. Now it pulls only .063A and does not loop boot.

1v5 LDO .460 diode mode on all 4 chips
3v3 LDO .449 / .460 all 4
PPBUS present at 0.6V

My readings for PPBUS are strange.  Measured at the ppbus fuse it climbs from 0 resistance to 5k resistance.  I've seen this before, it's normal?  Diode readings are similar: .320v to .420V over 10 seconds

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message:
Do you have known good battery connected?
This board model may not boot at all without battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message: Battery seems deadish.  200ma at <CAPACITOR>C6960</CAPACITOR> pin 1.   Is there a way to measure before the battery fets or do i just swap

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message: Did a swap, i hate these batteries.  Same deal with known good batt.  It pulls 5v .0063 A but SOMETIMES it grabs 20v and sticks at 100ma with either battery, connected or disconnected.  I leave it connected for 20 mins and it'll negotiate eventually. Though now it won't.  Tempted to put it in a reflow oven just to see.  Sigh.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message: It is recognized in DFU mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message: Doesn't seem to want to go to DFU, even using DFU force pads.  Immediately settles at 5v .0045A draw now.  Does not fluctuate, now doesn't get to 20V no matter how long.  I hate apple.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message: Check if SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages come on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message: Nope. And also my 3v3 g3h is missing/held down

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No visible damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> should be there; as you get 20V on USB-C ports.

Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> LDO outputs.
